summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, denying Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence and ordering the unsealing of several previously sealed documents, including a 2019 memorandum decision and transcripts of ex parte hearings.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20-cr-330) whose motions to suppress evidence are being denied by the court order.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge issuing the order, denying Maxwell's motions and ordering the unsealing of documents.

events.title: Court Denies Maxwell's Suppression Motions
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan denies Ghislaine Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence (Dkt. Nos. 133, 139) in her criminal case.

events.title: Memorandum Decision on Protective Order Modification
events.description: A memorandum decision and order was issued regarding the Government's application to modify the protective order in a related civil case (v. Maxwell, No. 15-cv-7433).

events.title: Ex Parte Hearing on Protective Order
events.description: An ex parte hearing was held regarding the Government's application to modify the protective order.

events.title: Second Ex Parte Hearing on Protective Order
events.description: A second ex parte hearing was held regarding the Government's application to modify the protective order.

keyFacts: Judge Alison J. Nathan denied Ghislaine Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence in her criminal case.
The court ordered the unsealing of a 2019 memorandum decision and order regarding modification of a protective order in a related civil case.
The court also ordered the unsealing of transcripts from March 26, 2019 and April 9, 2019 ex parte hearings on the protective order application.
The parties were given three days to propose redactions to the court's opinion and one week to propose redactions to the documents being unsealed.
The order references the Second Circuit's opinion in Lugosch v. Pyramid Co. of Onondaga as the legal standard for proposed redactions.
